items.content: Israeli prime minister faces protests inside and outside UN General Assembly deepening Israel's international isolation.

items.title: Netanyahu's speech: Main message was 'Israel against the world'
items.standfirst: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu vowed Friday (September 26) in an angry UN address to block a Palestinian state, accusing European leaders of pushing his country into "national suicide" and rewarding Hamas. FRANCE 24's Kethevane Gorjestani tells us more about his speech and gives us her analysis. "The main message of that speech was Israel against the world and it was portrayed physically within that UN General Assembly with that walkout of dozens and dozens of diplomats", she said.
items.content: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu vowed Friday (September 26) in an angry UN address to block a Palestinian state, accusing European leaders of pushing his country into "national suicide" and rewarding Hamas. FRANCE 24's Kethevane Gorjestani tells us more about his speech and gives us her analysis. "The main message of that speech was Israel against the world and it was portrayed physically within that UN General Assembly with that walkout of dozens and dozens of diplomats", she said.

items.title: Netanyahu tells UN that Israel ‘must finish the job’ in Gaza after dozens of delegates walk out in protest - as it happened
items.standfirst: Israeli PM rebuked Western nations for embracing Palestinian statehood after scores of delegates left the hall in protest. This live blog is closedNetanyahu vows to ‘finish job’ in Gaza during UN speech as delegates walk outPalestinians living in poverty were also affected, the Palestinian prime minister’s spokesperson Mohammad Abu al-Rob told Agence France-Presse (AFP), with their numbers rising by more than 150% since the start of the Gaza war, and with cash assistance not paid out in more than two months.An increase in the number of Israeli checkpoints in the West Bank, and a reduction in work permits for West Bank Palestinians seeking work inside Israel have had a drastic impact. Continue reading...

items.title: Israeli loudspeakers broadcast Netanyahu’s speech to UN into Gaza
items.standfirst: Operation prompts outrage as Israeli PM criticises western countries for recognising Palestine as a state and pledges to continue warNetanyahu vows to ‘finish job’ in Gaza during UN speech as delegates walk outIsraeli military loudspeaker systems have broadcast Benjamin Netanyahu’s speech to the UN into Gaza in an unprecedented operation that immediately prompted controversy and outrage.In a statement on Friday, an Israeli government spokesperson said: “As part of the public diplomacy effort, the prime minister’s office has directed civilian elements, in cooperation with the [Israel Defense Forces], to place loudspeakers on the backs of trucks on the Israeli side of the Gaza border so that Prime Minister Netanyahu’s historic UN general assembly speech will be heard in the Gaza Strip.” Continue reading...
items.content: Operation prompts outrage as Israeli PM criticises western countries for recognising Palestine as a state and pledges to continue warNetanyahu vows to ‘finish job’ in Gaza during UN speech as delegates walk outIsraeli military loudspeaker systems have broadcast Benjamin Netanyahu’s speech to the UN into Gaza in an unprecedented operation that immediately prompted controversy and outrage.In a statement on Friday, an Israeli government spokesperson said: “As part of the public diplomacy effort, the prime minister’s office has directed civilian elements, in cooperation with the [Israel Defense Forces], to place loudspeakers on the backs of trucks on the Israeli side of the Gaza border so that Prime Minister Netanyahu’s historic UN general assembly speech will be heard in the Gaza Strip.” Continue reading...

items.title: Takeaways from Benjamin Netanyahu's speech at the UN General Assembly
items.standfirst: Facing international isolation and a walkout by UN delegates, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Friday (September 26) said his country "must finish the job" against Hamas in Gaza in a defiant speech at the UN General Assembly. FRANCE 24's Jessica Le Masurier tells us more from New York.
items.content: Facing international isolation and a walkout by UN delegates, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Friday (September 26) said his country "must finish the job" against Hamas in Gaza in a defiant speech at the UN General Assembly. FRANCE 24's Jessica Le Masurier tells us more from New York.

items.content: Dozens of people filed out of the room in protest at the United Nations General Assembly in New York.

items.content: Facing down a mass walkout and mounting diplomatic pressure, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu vowed Friday to “finish the job” as he defied growing isolation over his military’s devastating assault on the Gaza Strip

The Prime Minister accused European leaders of pushing Israel toward "national suicide".
Palestinian poverty has increased significantly since the start of the Gaza war.

clusters.title: Assata Shakur, a fugitive Black militant sought by the U.S. since 1979, dies in Cuba
clusters.neutral_headline: Assata Shakur, Black Liberation Activist, Dies in Cuba at 78
bullet_summary: Officials in New Jersey, where Shakur had been arrested, convicted and imprisoned, said she was 78
Reported by NPR News, CBS News, BBC World and others

items.title: Assata Shakur, a fugitive Black militant sought by the U.S. since 1979, dies in Cuba
items.standfirst: Assata Shakur, a Black liberation activist who was given political asylum in Cuba after her 1979 escape from a U.S. prison, has died. Officials in New Jersey, where Shakur had been arrested, convicted and imprisoned, said she was 78.
items.content: Assata Shakur, a Black liberation activist who was given political asylum in Cuba after her 1979 escape from a U.S. prison, has died. Officials in New Jersey, where Shakur had been arrested, convicted and imprisoned, said she was 78.(Image credit: AP)

items.title: Assata Shakur dies in Cuba after decades on the run
items.standfirst: Assata Shakur, also known as Joanne Chesimard, was convicted of murdering a state trooper in 1973 and escaped prison in 1979.
items.content: Assata Shakur, also known as Joanne Chesimard, was convicted of murdering a state trooper in 1973 and escaped prison in 1979.

items.title: Assata Shakur, black liberation activist exiled in Cuba, dies at 78
items.standfirst: She fled to Cuba after being convicted in the killing of a police officer but denied the shooting.
items.content: She fled to Cuba after being convicted in the killing of a police officer but denied the shooting.

items.title: Assata Shakur, US Black liberation activist exiled in Cuba, dies at 78
items.standfirst: The fugitive revolutionary spent decades in exile after escaping from a US jail in 1979.
items.content: The fugitive revolutionary spent decades in exile after escaping from a US jail in 1979.

items.title: Assata Shakur, an icon of Black liberation who was exiled to Cuba, dies aged 78
items.standfirst: Shakur spent decades exiled after she was convicted of killing a state trooper in 1977 and escaped from prisonOn 25 September, Assata Shakur, a former member of the Black Liberation Army, died aged 78 in Havana, Cuba, according to Cuba’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Cuban officials cited the reason for her death as old age and health conditions. Shakur, a longstanding symbol of resistance and Black liberation, spent several decades exiled in Cuba after she was convicted of killing a New Jersey state trooper in 1977 and escaped from prison.“At approximately 1:15pm on September 25th, my mother, Assata Shakur, took her last earthly breath,” her daughter Kakuya Shakur wrote on Facebook. “Words cannot describe the depth of loss that I’m feeling at this time.” Continue reading...
items.content: Shakur spent decades exiled after she was convicted of killing a state trooper in 1977 and escaped from prisonOn 25 September, Assata Shakur, a former member of the Black Liberation Army, died aged 78 in Havana, Cuba, according to Cuba’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Cuban officials cited the reason for her death as old age and health conditions. Shakur, a longstanding symbol of resistance and Black liberation, spent several decades exiled in Cuba after she was convicted of killing a New Jersey state trooper in 1977 and escaped from prison.“At approximately 1:15pm on September 25th, my mother, Assata Shakur, took her last earthly breath,” her daughter Kakuya Shakur wrote on Facebook. “Words cannot describe the depth of loss that I’m feeling at this time.” Continue reading...

items.title: Assata Shakur, Black Liberation Army member convicted of killing a state trooper, dies at 78
items.standfirst: Black liberation activist and American fugitive Assata Shakur, who escaped to Cuba more than 45 years ago after she was convicted of killing a New Jersey state trooper, died in Havana, the government announced Friday.
items.content: Black liberation activist and American fugitive Assata Shakur, who escaped to Cuba more than 45 years ago after she was convicted of killing a New Jersey state trooper, died in Havana, the government announced Friday.

ai_summary: Assata Shakur, a Black liberation activist, died in Cuba at the age of 78.
She was granted political asylum in Cuba after escaping from a US prison in 1979.
Shakur was convicted of murdering a state trooper in 1973.
Cuban officials cited old age and health conditions as the cause of death.
Her daughter wrote of the depth of loss she was feeling at this time.

items.content: A lower court had previously ordered Trump to disburse the congressionally approved aid before its expiration date.

items.standfirst: The Supreme Court allowed the Trump administration to withhold more than $4 billion in foreign aid funding through a maneuver known as a "pocket rescission."
items.content: The Supreme Court allowed the Trump administration to withhold more than $4 billion in foreign aid funding through a maneuver known as a "pocket rescission."

items.title: Supreme Court allows Trump to withhold $4 billion in foreign aid funding
items.standfirst: The Supreme Court handed another win to the Trump administration by allowing it to withhold $4 billion in spending on foreign aid that was approved by Congress.
items.content: The Supreme Court handed another win to the Trump administration by allowing it to withhold $4 billion in spending on foreign aid that was approved by Congress.

ai_summary: The Supreme Court allowed the Trump administration to withhold $4 billion in foreign aid.
The aid was approved by Congress for the current fiscal year.
The court's decision overturned a lower court's ruling.
The court cited Trump's foreign policy authority as the reason for the decision.
This was the 20th win for the Trump administration on the emergency docket.

clusters.title: ByteDance to Get About 50% of TikTok US Profit Under Trump Deal
clusters.neutral_headline: TikTok Deal: ByteDance to Retain Profit Share, Valuation Concerns
bullet_summary: Trump said he and China’s president Xi Jinping had come to an agreement to allow TikTok to continue operating in the US, separating the social media platform from its Chinese owner ByteDance
Trump said the deal complies with a law that would have forced the shutdown of the app for American users had it not been divested and sold to a US owner

items.title: ByteDance to Get About 50% of TikTok US Profit Under Trump Deal
items.standfirst: TikTok’s Chinese parent company will likely get about half of the profit from the platform’s US operation even after it sells majority ownership to American investors as part of a deal orchestrated by President Donald Trump, according to people familiar with the matter.
items.content: TikTok’s Chinese parent company will likely get about half of the profit from the platform’s US operation even after it sells majority ownership to American investors as part of a deal orchestrated by President Donald Trump, according to people familiar with the matter.

items.title: TikTok Gets $14 Billion Proposed Price Tag in Trump Deal
items.standfirst: The $14 billion price tag for TikTok’s US business cited by Vice President JD Vance on Thursday is well below previous projections that scaled closer to $40 billion. The estimate comes as President Donald Trump pushes forward a plan for American investors to buy the US operation from Chinese internet firm ByteDance Ltd. Tyler Kendall reports on Bloomberg Television.
items.content: The $14 billion price tag for TikTok’s US business cited by Vice President JD Vance on Thursday is well below previous projections that scaled closer to $40 billion. The estimate comes as President Donald Trump pushes forward a plan for American investors to buy the US operation from Chinese internet firm ByteDance Ltd. Tyler Kendall reports on Bloomberg Television.

items.title: TikTok’s $14 Billion Valuation in Trump Deal Stuns Investors
items.standfirst: The $14 billion valuation that the Trump administration has estimated for TikTok’s US business falls well below projections, surprising investors who say a deal at that price would be a bargain for potential buyers including Larry Ellison’s Oracle Corp. and partner Silver Lake Management LLC.
items.content: The $14 billion valuation that the Trump administration has estimated for TikTok’s US business falls well below projections, surprising investors who say a deal at that price would be a bargain for potential buyers including Larry Ellison’s Oracle Corp. and partner Silver Lake Management LLC.

items.title: Trump signs executive order to transfer TikTok to US owners
items.standfirst: Agreement separates app from Chinese owner ByteDance and allows US investors to take 80% stakeDonald Trump signed an executive order on Thursday outlining the terms of a deal to transfer TikTok to a US owner.Trump said he and China’s president Xi Jinping had come to an agreement to allow TikTok to continue operating in the US, separating the social media platform from its Chinese owner ByteDance. Trump said the deal complies with a law that would have forced the shutdown of the app for American users had it not been divested and sold to a US owner. Continue reading...
items.content: Agreement separates app from Chinese owner ByteDance and allows US investors to take 80% stakeDonald Trump signed an executive order on Thursday outlining the terms of a deal to transfer TikTok to a US owner.Trump said he and China’s president Xi Jinping had come to an agreement to allow TikTok to continue operating in the US, separating the social media platform from its Chinese owner ByteDance. Trump said the deal complies with a law that would have forced the shutdown of the app for American users had it not been divested and sold to a US owner. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump Executive Order Will Hand TikTok Over to US Investors
items.standfirst: After five deadline extensions and several rounds of negotiations, President Trump signed an executive order to put TikTok’s US operations in the hands of Oracle and other American investors.
items.content: After five deadline extensions and several rounds of negotiations, President Trump signed an executive order to put TikTok’s US operations in the hands of Oracle and other American investors.

items.title: Trump Signs TikTok Order With US App Valued at $14 Billion
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump advanced plans for American investors to buy TikTok’s US operations from its Chinese owner ByteDance Ltd., with officials setting a potential value of $14 billion and outlining measures to ensure security of the new venture.
items.content: President Donald Trump advanced plans for American investors to buy TikTok’s US operations from its Chinese owner ByteDance Ltd., with officials setting a potential value of $14 billion and outlining measures to ensure security of the new venture.

ai_summary: ByteDance will likely get about half of TikTok's US profit.
This is part of a deal orchestrated by President Donald Trump.
The $14 billion valuation is well below previous projections.
Trump signed an executive order to transfer TikTok to US owners.
The deal allows US investors to take an 80% stake in TikTok.

items.content: French ex-president Nicolas Sarkozy's bombshell conviction in a Libyan funding probe has elicited starkly opposing reactions from left and right, exposing France's political divide.

items.title: Reactions to former French President Sarkozy's jail sentence
items.standfirst: The dramatic decision to send former president Nicolas Sarkozy to prison for criminal conspiracy has laid bare France's stark political divisions, with the move cheered by the left but slammed by the ascendant right.
items.content: The dramatic decision to send former president Nicolas Sarkozy to prison for criminal conspiracy has laid bare France's stark political divisions, with the move cheered by the left but slammed by the ascendant right.

items.title: Sarkozy says he will ‘sleep in jail but with head held high’ after conviction
items.standfirst: Former French president receives five-year prison sentence for criminal conspiracy over pact with Gaddafi regimeThe former French president Nicolas Sarkozy said he would “sleep in jail but with my head held high” after receiving a five-year prison sentence for criminal conspiracy – the first time a former head of state has been sent to prison in modern French history.The verdict and sentencing followed a trial in which he and his aides were accused of making a corruption pact with the regime of the late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi to receive funding for the 2007 French presidential election campaign. Continue reading...
items.content: Former French president receives five-year prison sentence for criminal conspiracy over pact with Gaddafi regimeThe former French president Nicolas Sarkozy said he would “sleep in jail but with my head held high” after receiving a five-year prison sentence for criminal conspiracy – the first time a former head of state has been sent to prison in modern French history.The verdict and sentencing followed a trial in which he and his aides were accused of making a corruption pact with the regime of the late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi to receive funding for the 2007 French presidential election campaign. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Nicolas Sarkozy received a prison sentence.
The sentence is for criminal conspiracy.
The conviction has exposed political divisions in France.
The left cheered the move.
The right condemned the decision.
